 215378 | 2015-11-23 20:00:11 | Science    | Earth not due for a geomagnetic flip in the near future, researchers show                                      | http://phys.org/news/2015-11-earth-due-geomagnetic-flip-future.html                                                                                    |                   | 2015-11-24 11:23:18.889188 | earth sciences                                                                                                                                     | The intensity of Earth's geomagnetic field has been dropping for the past 200 years, at a rate that some scientists suspect may cause the field to bottom out in 2,000 years, temporarily leaving the planet unprotected against damaging charged particles from the sun. This drop in intensity is associated with periodic geomagnetic field reversals, in which the Earth's North and South magnetic poles flip polarity, and it could last for several thousand years before returning to a stable, shielding intensity.
 215452 | 2015-11-23 16:34:40 | Technology | Today in Engineering History: Europe's First Weather Satellite Launches                                        | http://www.pddnet.com/news/2015/11/today-engineering-history-europes-first-weather-satellite-launches                                                  | mcrouse           | 2015-11-24 11:28:31.489568 |                                                                                                                                                    | <div class="field field-name-field-content-item-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">News</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-summary field-type-text-long field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Today in 1977, the European Space Agency launched Meteosat-1, Europe’s first weather satellite. These satellites provided continuous meteorological information for use in TV weather bulletins. Meteosat-1 was the first... </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-featured-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="/news/2015/11/today-engineering-history-europes-first-weather-satellite-launches"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.pddnet.com/sites/pddnet.com/files/styles/wide_thumb/public/embedded_image/2015/08/engineering%20history.jpg?itok=AHOM_XAl" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-staff-author field-type-node-reference field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Staff Author:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="/staff-author/megan-crouse-0">Megan Crouse</a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-taxonomy field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Topics:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="/topics/aerospace" typeof="skos:Concept" property="rdfs:label skos:prefLabel" datatype="">Aerospace</a></div></div></div>
 216170 | 2015-11-24 17:03:47 | Science    | Physicists entangle qubits in a semiconductor at room temperature                                              | http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/2015/nov/24/physicists-entangle-qubits-in-a-semiconductor-at-room-temperature                                 |                   | 2015-12-22 12:38:05.782569 |                                                                                                                                                    | In addition to quantum-computing applications, the system could be used as an <i>in vivo</i> biological sensor<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/PhysicsWorld/~4/N-gHwMdoCrQ" height="1" width="1" alt=""/>
 216270 | 2015-11-25 11:20:30 | Science    | Physicists set quantum record by using photons to carry messages from electrons almost 2 kilometers apart      | http://phys.org/news/2015-11-physicists-quantum-photons-messages-electrons.html                                                                        |                   | 2015-12-22 12:39:34.888766 | quantum physics                                                                                                                                    | Researchers from Stanford have advanced a long-standing problem in quantum physics – how to send "entangled" particles over long distances.
 216326 | 2015-11-25 05:00:00 | Science    | CERN collides heavy nuclei at new record high energy                                                           | http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2015-11/uoc--cch112515.php                                                                                      |                   | 2015-12-22 12:40:22.915959 |                                                                                                                                                    | (<i>University of Copenhagen - Niels Bohr Institute</i>) The world's most powerful accelerator, the 27 km long Large Hadron Collider operating at CERN in Geneva established collisions between lead nuclei, this morning, at the highest energies ever. The experiments aim at understanding and studying the properties of strongly interacting systems at high densities and thus the state of matter of the Universe shortly after the Big Bang.
 216460 | 2015-11-25 05:00:00 | Technology | New gene map reveals cancer's Achilles heel                                                                    | http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2015-11/uot-ngm112515.php                                                                                       |                   | 2015-12-21 17:18:53.500452 |                                                                                                                                                    | (<i>University of Toronto</i>) Scientists have mapped out the genes that keep our cells alive, creating a long-awaited foothold for understanding how our genome works and which genes are crucial in disease like cancer.
 216515 | 2015-11-25 17:49:27 | Astronomy  | CERN Replicates Post-Big-Bang Universe --"Quarks, Antiquarks and Gluons Over 4000 billion Degrees Temperature" | http://www.dailygalaxy.com/my_weblog/2015/11/cern-creates-post-big-bang-primordial-soup-quarks-antiquarks-and-gluons-over-4000-billion-degrees-te.html | dailygalaxy.com   | 2015-12-22 12:42:00.861183 |                                                                                                                                                    | <div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><p> </p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p> </p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p><a class="asset-img-link" href="http://www.dailygalaxy.com/.a/6a00d8341bf7f753ef01bb0895712a970d-pi" style="display: inline;"><img alt="View_inside_detector_at_the_CMS_cavern_LHC_CERN" border="0" class="asset  asset-image at-xid-6a00d8341bf7f753ef01bb0895712a970d image-full img-responsive" src="http://www.dailygalaxy.com/.a/6a00d8341bf7f753ef01bb0895712a970d-800wi" title="View_inside_detector_at_the_CMS_cavern_LHC_CERN"></img></a><br><br><br></p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p> </p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p>The world's most powerful accelerator, the 27 km long Large Hadron Collider (LHC) operating at CERN in Geneva established collisions between lead nuclei, this morning, at the highest energies ever. The LHC has been colliding protons at record high energy since the summer, but now the time has now come to collide large nuclei (nuclei of lead, Pb, consist of 208 neutrons and protons). The experiments aim at understanding and studying the properties of strongly interacting systems at high densities and thus the state of matter of the Universe shortly after the Big Bang.</p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | In the very beginning, just a few billionths of a second after the Big Bang, the Universe was made up of an extremely hot and dense 'primordial soup' consisting of the fundamental particles, especially quarks and gluons. This state is called the quark-gluon-plasma (<a class="zem_slink" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quark%E2%80%93gluon_plasma" rel="wikipedia" target="_blank" title="Quark–gluon plasma">QGP</a>). Approximately one millionth of a second after the Big Bang, quarks and gluons became confined inside the protons and the neutrons, which are the present day constituents of the atomic nuclei.\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p>The so-called strong force, mediated by the gluons, binds the quarks to each other and - under normal circumstances, trap them inside the nuclear particles. It is however, possible to recreate a state of matter consisting of quarks and gluons, and which behaves as a liquid, in close imitation of the state of matter prevailing in the very early universe. It is this state that has now been realised at the highest temperatures ever attained in collisions using lead ions from the LHC accelerator at CERN.</p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p>"The collision energy between two nuclei reaches 1000 TeV. This energy is that of a bumblebee hitting us on the cheek on a summer day. But the energy is concentrated in a volume that is approximately 10-27 (a billion-billion-billion) times smaller. The energy concentration (density) is therefore tremendous and has never been realised before under terrestrial conditions," explains Jens Jørgen Gaardhøje, professor at the <a class="zem_slink" href="http://maps.google.com/maps?ll=55.6967472222,12.5713333333&amp;spn=0.01,0.01&amp;q=55.6967472222,12.5713333333 (Niels%20Bohr%20Institute)&amp;t=h" rel="geolocation" target="_blank" title="Niels Bohr Institute">Niels Bohr Institute</a> at the <a class="zem_slink" href="http://maps.google.com/maps?ll=55.6797222222,12.5725&amp;spn=0.01,0.01&amp;q=55.6797222222,12.5725 (University%20of%20Copenhagen)&amp;t=h" rel="geolocation" target="_blank" title="University of Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a> and head of the Danish research group within the <a class="zem_slink" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Large_Ion_Collider_Experiment" rel="wikipedia" target="_blank" title="A Large Ion Collider Experiment">ALICE experiment</a> at CERN.</p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p> </p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p><a class="asset-img-link" href="http://www.dailygalaxy.com/.a/6a00d8341bf7f753ef01b8d17b0da8970c-pi" style="display: inline;"><img alt="Cerncollides" border="0" class="asset  asset-image at-xid-6a00d8341bf7f753ef01b8d17b0da8970c image-full img-responsive" src="http://www.dailygalaxy.com/.a/6a00d8341bf7f753ef01b8d17b0da8970c-800wi" title="Cerncollides"></img></a></p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p> </p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p>Jens Jørgen Gaardhøje explains that the purpose of the collisions is to transform most of the enormous kinetic energy of the colliding atomic nuclei into matter, in the form of a host of new particles (quarks) and their antiparticles (antiquarks) in compliance with Einstein's famous equation E=Mc2. This creates - for a fleeting moment, a small volume of matter consisting of quarks, antiquarks and gluons that has a temperature of over 4000 billion degrees.</p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p>The first collisions were recorded by the LHC detectors, including the dedicated heavy-ion detector ALICE, which has significant Danish participation, immediately after the LHC's two counter-circulating beams were aimed at each other this morning at 11:15 AM.</p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p>"While it is still too early for a full analysis to have been carried out, the first collisions already tell us that more than 30,000 particles can be created in every central collision between two lead ions. This corresponds to an unprecedented energy density of around 20 GeV/fm3. This is more than 40 times the energy density of a proton," says Jens Jørgen Gaardhøje.</p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p>The extreme energy density will enable researchers to develop new and detailed models of the quark-gluon-plasma and of the strong interaction, which binds the quarks and nuclear matter together and thus understand the conditions prevailing in the early universe all the way back to a billionth of a second after the Big Bang.</p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <p>The Daily Galaxy via University of Copenhagen/Neils Bohr Institute</p>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              +
        |                     |            |                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                        |                   |                            |                                                                                                                                                    | <fieldset class="zemanta-related"><legend class="zemanta-related-title">Related articles</legend>\r                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    +
